response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms that the robot's end-effector is positioned to grasp the man’s neck (likely his neck muscles near the jawline or side of neck), with the wrist close to the skin. The environment is a cluttered table with various objects but none obstructing the robot-man interaction. The man’s neck is soft tissue, covered with skin and underlying muscles, requiring delicate but firm manipulation. The robot gripper contacts the neck laterally, implying the grasp is around the side of the neck with moderate force to avoid discomfort or injury while allowing manipulation for massage. The wrist is mounted on the robot arm, oriented so the grasp and manipulations occur close to the man’s neck without external support. Gravity acts downward, but the neck is supported by the man's body and table surface nearby.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such:
- Wrist X-axis (red) points roughly horizontally from the robot towards the man’s neck (parallel to the man’s neck width axis).
- Wrist Y-axis (green) points roughly upward along the neck direction (roughly vertical, following the neck from shoulder to head).
- Wrist Z-axis (blue) points roughly outward from the wrist into the neck (perpendicular to the skin surface at contact), roughly forward in world frame into the workspace (camera view).

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion inward and outward normal to the neck’s skin surface in the world, i.e., pressing into or releasing from the neck.

Based on the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object (neck surface) must move slightly inward and outward relative to the gripper (small amplitude oscillations) to perform pressing and releasing massage actions.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to horizontal side-to-side motion across the man's neck in the world frame (roughly left-right relative to the man's perspective).

Based on the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object (neck) must move side to side under the gripper to execute lateral sliding massage motions.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It corresponds roughly to vertical motions upward and downward along the neck’s length.

Based on the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object can be moved in a slow rising and lowering motion to vary pressure and perform kneading along muscle fibers.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object's required motion is minor oscillations in Z (press & release), smooth side-to-side translations in X, combined with gentle up-down movements in Y over the massage duration.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: The robot must exert positive and negative cyclic side forces of about ±10 N to perform gentle lateral sliding massage.

Linear Y-axis: The robot must exert positive and negative small forces ±5 N to modulate pressure and provide vertical kneading along neck muscles.

Linear Z-axis: The robot must exert cyclic positive forces up to 15 N pressing into the neck surface and reduce force during release phases; this provides the main massage pressure.

Angular X-axis: The robot must apply slight torque (clockwise and counterclockwise) about X-axis (~0.5 N·m) to conform the gripper to neck curvature during kneading.

Angular Y-axis: Minor angular adjustments about Y-axis (±0.3 N·m) for wrist tilt to maintain consistent contact pressure across neck irregularities.

Angular Z-axis: Minimal angular torque needed (~0.1 N·m) for rotation around the grasp axis to align gripper with neck muscle fibers.

Grasping force: Given the softness and sensitivity of the neck, and to maintain stable contact without pain, a gentle grasping force ranging from 8 to 12 N is estimated. This provides enough friction to avoid slippage but minimizes discomfort.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# The robot interacts with a human neck: soft tissue with skin covering muscles, requiring gentle forces.
# Estimated neck tissue compliance is moderate; friction between robot gripper and skin is moderate to high due to soft contact and possible slight moisture.
# Mass of neck tissue is negligible relative to forces applied; main resistance due to tissue elasticity and human reaction.
# Estimated friction coefficient ~0.6, estimated resistance to lateral sliding ~5-10 N.
property_description = "Human neck soft tissue, skin-covered, compliant, friction coefficient approx 0.6, requiring gentle interaction forces."

# Motion combines oscillatory pressing in Z (normal to skin), lateral sliding in X, and slow vertical kneading in Y.
wrist_motion_description = "Cyclic inward-outward pressing motion in Z (~±2 cm), lateral sliding in X (~±3 cm), slow vertical up-down movement in Y (~±1.5 cm) to perform a thorough neck massage."

# Motion amplitudes in meters along wrist axes: X: ±0.03 m, Y: ±0.015 m, Z: ±0.02 m
# Represented as peak displacements; actual motion oscillates about initial grasp position.
wrist_motion_vector = [0.03, 0.015, 0.02]

# Forces and torques required to maintain contact, produce massage pressure and motion:
# Linear forces: X-axis ±10 N (lateral massage), Y-axis ±5 N (vertical kneading), Z-axis up to 15 N (pressing)
# Torques: angular X ~±0.5 N·m, angular Y ~±0.3 N·m, angular Z ~±0.1 N·m for wrist compliance and muscle fiber alignment.
wrist_wrench = [10, 5, 15, 0.5, 0.3, 0.1]

# Grasping force range estimated to be gentle but firm enough to prevent slippage without discomfort
grasp_force = 10

# Estimated task duration of 5 minutes (300 seconds) to provide thorough massage
duration = 300
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
